Meanwhile, two expatriates from Wings' sister series Cheers -- Norm (George Wendt) and Cliff (John Ratzenberger) -- show up on the island with fishing poles in their hands and big hopes in their hearts.

Although Helen (Crystal Bernard) is anxious over the prospect of auditioning for Edward Tinsdale (David Ogden Stiers), the conductor of the prestigious Minneapolis Philharmonic Symphony, Joe (Tim Daly) and Brian (Steven Weber) urge her to take the chance. Nervously, Helen grabs her cello and capitalizes on Tinsdale's visit to Nantucket. Unfortunately, our heroine's timing is a wee bit off: Tinsdale is on his honeymoon, and is understandably put out over being bothered with business matters!

Rival airline owner Roy (David Schramm) would love to be as popular and convivial as Joe (Tim Daly) and Brian (Steven Weber), but he is operating under a handicap -- nobody can stand Roy, and the feeling is mutual. All this may change when Roy decides to practice the edicts of "The Golden Rule" as laid down by helpful Joe. Then again, a "nice" Roy has every potential of being just as obnoxious as the nasty one.

Joe (Tim Daly) receives an unexpected phone call from an old high school pal (played by Kelly Cannell) -- in fact, according to the party on the other line, he was once Joe's best friend. Within seconds, Joe has agreed to be best man at the old chum's wedding, which is to be held in Nantucket. There's just one hitch -- Joe can't remember anything at all about his long-ago pal, including what the guy looks like.

Joe (Tim Daly) and Brian (Steven Weber) persist in their efforts to prove that they are much, much more than friends to Helen (Crystal Bernard). With her birthday approaching, both brothers are determined to bowl her over with the generosity of their gifts. Alas, the hunt for a suitable present morphs into yet another bitter sibling-rivalry battle, with those selfsame presents as weapons of near-mass destruction! This episode is highlighted by a tantalizing home-movie glimpse into the childhood of the three principals.

Persistent policewoman Colleen Thomas (Sharon Barr) has set her sights on swinging bachelor Brian (Steven Weber), who had only come onto her to prevent his brother Joe (Tim Daly) from being arrested for Brian's unpaid parking tickets. Sensing that Brian doesn't want the relationship with Colleen to blossom, Helen (Crystal Bernard) suggests that he discourage the policewoman with a "little white lie." Brian takes the advice -- only to get into deep trouble by weaving a fabrication of his own invention, rather than the harmless falsehood concocted by Helen.

Joe (Tim Daly) has been temporarily grounded from flying due to high blood pressure. At first welcoming the opportunity to be a desk jockey for a while, Joe soon grows weary of his inactivity -- and increasingly hostile toward the devil-may-care attitude of Sandpiper Air's remaining pilot, his brother Brian (Steven Weber). One thing leads to another, and by mid-episode Joe has blown his stack and fired his own brother! And just when the situation couldn't get worse, in comes rival airline owner Roy (David Schramm) with an offer to buy Sandpiper, an offer which Joe is presently in no position to refuse.

Although Joe (Tim Daly) and Helen (Crystal Bernard) have been friends since childhood, their fondness towards one another has not blossomed into a full romance -- yet. All this may change when Joe and Helen, both facing a dateless weekend, decide to go out to dinner together, then park for a while at Indian Point, the local passion pit. The mood, alas, is shattered when the couple finds they have parked near the car owned by the high school kid whom Joe has just hired as a backup pilot for Sandpiper Air. Michael Manasseri makes his first series appearance as Kenneth McElvey.

Macho airline owner Roy (David Schramm) surprises one an all by allowing his high-school football star son R.J. (Abraham Benrubi) to take cello lessons from Helen (Crystal Bernard). It turns out that Roy is amused at the prospect of his son having a crush on Helen, who works for his chief rivals the Hackett brothers. Well, R.J. does have romance on his mind, all right...but it isn't the sort of romance that Roy could ever have imagined! This episode had originally been slated for Wings' first season, but was withheld because of its sensitive subject matter.

Created by several of the same people responsible for Cheers, Wings began its first season in a Thursday-night time slot right after its "sister" series. In the opening episode viewers are introduced to Joe Hackett (Tim Daly), the no-nonsense owner of Sandpiper Air, a one-plane charter service headquartered on Nantucket Island. When his father dies, Joe receives as his legacy a strange sealed box -- and is also reluctantly reunited with his scapegrace brother Brian (Steven Weber) who, six years earlier, had run off with Joe's fianc√©e Carol. Upon opening the box, the two brothers are immediately sent off on a wild-goose chase -- which turns out to be their late father's puckish method to bring Joe and Brian back together again.

When would-be concert cellist Helen (Crystal Bernard) finally receives a callback for a symphony audition, her old pal Brian (Steven Weber) suggests that she might improve her chances if she dressed a little more...invitingly. Elsewhere, Fay (Rebecca Schull) provides moral support to aging pilot Howard Banks (Richard Erdman) who is on the last lap of a two-year flight around the world. Banks is convinced that an earlier "pact with God" will result in his immediate demise the moment his journey ends, and Fay does her best to convince him otherwise.

In the first half of a two-part story, brothers Joe (Tim Daly) and Brian (Steven Weber) are once again two cogs in a never-ending romantic wheel. Brian's ex-wife Carol (Kim Ulrich), who had dumped Joe in favor of Brian six years ago, subsequently divested herself of Brian to pursue another man. Now, the "other man" is history, as are several of Carol's interim romances. When Brian finds out that Carol is making a stopover in Boston en route to London, he decides to re-spark the old flame, choosing the Prudential Building as their meeting place (not quite Sleepless in Seattle, but it'll do).

In the conclusion of a two-part story, Brian (Steven Weber) has reunited with his ex Carol (Kim Ulrich), who also has a history with Brian's brother Joe (Tim Daly). Figuring to be the final victor in this sibling struggle, Brian whisks Carol off for a (hopefully) romantic rendezvous in Nantucket. But Carol can't get Joe off her mind, and before long it looks as though the saga of the Hackett brothers' battle over the same woman has entered a new phase -- or is it simply the same old phase all over again?

Freewheeling Brian (Steven Weber) arranges a blind date between his uptight brother Joe (Tim Daly) and local girl Cindy (a pre-Will & Grace Megan Mullally). The problem is that Cindy has "known" (in the Biblical sense) virtually every adult male in Nantucket -- including Brian. This situation plays itself out in a riotous double date, from which both Joe and Brian emerge with battle scars aplenty!

Joe (Steven Weber) is called away to an emergency airport committee meeting (concerning the endangered "short-eared owl") on the same night he is to attend a Boston Celtics game with Helen (Crystal Bernard). In the spirit of brotherly love, Brian (Steven Weber) offers to escort Helen to the game himself. Joe is agreeable to this, but radically changes his mind -- and his mood -- when he learns that the game has been canceled, and figures out that Joe and Helen seem to be in no hurry to return to Nantucket. This is the final episode of Wings' six-week inaugural season.
Season 3 premiere. An examination of the global politics of a dangerous new Cold War as tensions between the U.S. and Russia are ratcheting up.

A look at the legal entanglements surrounding President Trump, including the Mueller investigation and the Michael Cohen raid. Also: interviews with attorneys Michael Avenatti and Alan Dershowitz; and former acting U.S. attorney general Sally Yates.

Mike Pompeo's nomination for Secretary of State; and state visits by French president Emmanuel Macron and German chancellor Angela Merkel are discussed. Also: former state department official Wendy Sherman on the Iran nuclear deal; Muslim Association of Hawaii imam Ismail Elshikh on President Trump's travel ban.

Celebrated Republican political strategist Steve Schmidt joins John Heilemann, Mark McKinnon and Alex Wagner as a guest host this week. From the industrial heartland to the Mountain West, and from the far North to the deep South, the team assesses Trump's impact on the national political climate, campaigns and candidates from both parties.
President Trump's first 100 days in office are the focus, as Season 2 begins.

The groundbreaking real-time political documentary series about America's presidential campaign returns, examining the unprecedented events unfolding in Donald Trump's administration. Journalists Mark Halperin and John Heilemann take the pulse of the country beyond the beltway while pulling back the curtain on a White House unlike any that has come before. -- (C) SHOWTIME

What do people outside the Beltway really think about President Trump? Mark Halperin takes a trip through America to find the answers. Then he heads to New Orleans to discuss his surprising findings with Mary Matalin.  -- (C) SHOWTIME

What in the world is going on? Mark Halperin heads to Palm Beach for Chinese President Xi Jinping's visit to Mar-A-Lago. A revealing look at how President Trump is handling American foreign policy and our relations with China.  -- (C) SHOWTIME

Congress may be in recess but Mark Halperin is on the job, covering the White House and the Syria fallout. John Heilemann and Mark McKinnon hit the road to see what Americans think about how President Trump is handling the situation. -- (C) SHOWTIME

Mark Halperin talks with Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.) about standing strong against Trump; Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.) tells John Heilemann about taking his message to the people; Americans discuss what resistance means to them.

As Congress reconvenes, Mark McKinnon and John Heilemann head to Capitol Hill to find out what President Trump has learned in his first 100 days in office. Also, Mark Halperin goes to New York City to get Wall Street's perspective.

Washington insiders join John Heilemann, Mark Halperin and Mark McKinnon for a look at some of the thrilling, amazing and logic defying acts performed during President Trump's first 100 days. Season finale. -- (C) SHOWTIME
A real-time documentary series that offers a revealing look at the 2016 presidential race. In the opener, Ted Cruz, Bernie Sanders and Donald Trump campaign in Iowa.
A real-time documentary series that offers a revealing look at the 2016 presidential race.

A look at the angst and drama leading up to the Iowa Caucuses, with a showdown brewing between Democrats Bernie Sanders and Hillary Clinton, and the GOP's first real test of outsider candidates versus the establishment.
A look at the Iowa fallout and an examination of who has momentum going into the New Hampshire primary, and whether Trump and Clinton can pick up the pace to beat back the surging Cruz and Sanders.
The candidates deal with the jolt that was New Hampshire and prepare for hard truths in South Carolina and Nevada.
Anxiety grows among the candidates about the high stakes in South Carolina and Nevada, and the significance of falling behind.

With the field narrowed down to The Big Five, the campaigns spread their game across the country and play to their strengths--with eyes squarely focused on the all-important upcoming prize: Super Tuesday.
Candidates who trail the front-runners deal with the results of Super Tuesday, while the Democratic and Republican establishments try to find a way to stop Trump.
Rubio, Kasich and Sanders pin their hopes on Florida and Ohio in hopes of gaining enough momentum to force a brokered convention.
As Rubio gets trumped in Florida, the rest of the field remains optimistic.  -- (C) Showtime
Benedict Arnold rounds up spies in New York; and Abe plots to destroy essential British supplies, but he will need his father's help.
When one of the Culper Ring members is captured, Arnold seeks to interrogate him with the help of a ruthless Col. Simcoe.
Abe's scheme to rescue Caleb turns deadly; Anna faces a difficult decision; and Arnold suspects Peggy is keeping a secret from him.
Amidst a growing rebellion in camp, the Culper Ring must chart a new course; Arnold finds an unlikely ally; and Rivington teaches Townsend a lesson.
Seeking revenge against Simcoe, Abe travels to New York and meets Benedict Arnold. Meanwhile, a visitor from Anna's past comes to the continental camp.
The plot to kidnap Benedict Arnold is hatched; Peggy learns Cicero's secret; and Washington and the French clash over strategy.
Ben's plan to kidnap Benedict Arnold conflicts with Abe's plot to kill Simcoe; and shifting loyalties turn old enemies into allies.
As Abe is thrust into battle, Ben appeals to Gen. Washington. Townsend risks everything, while Caleb seeks redemption.
After receiving Abe's intel, Washington heads south to lay siege on Yorktown; Abe volunteers for the Continental Army; and Peggy goes into labor.
In the series finale, the American War of Independence comes to an end, as America struggles to begin; and there's a settling of accounts between shadows and spies.
In the third-season premiere, Abe covers up a murder with an unlikely accomplice. Elsewhere, Benedict Arnold abuses his power as he settles into a new home in Philadelphia.
Anna tries to save the ring after Abe's cover is blown; and Benedict Arnold seeks Washington's help against charges of treason. Meanwhile, Townsend sends a signal.
Peggy manipulates Benedict Arnold into contacting the British; and Caleb sets an ambush for Simcoe. Meanwhile, Anna tries to save Major Hewlett's life.
Ben is rescued by a mysterious woman; Abe tries to stop Anna from marrying Hewlett; and Arnold begins negotiations with the British. Meanwhile, Andre betrays Peggy.
Townsend uncovers a British counterfeiting operation; and Rogers threatens to destroy Abe's spying ring. Meanwhile, Simcoe threatens Richard.
Washington attends Benedict Arnold's ball in Philadelphia; and Abe races to stop Rogers before he reaches Townsend. Meanwhile, old friends and enemies intersect.
Mary tries to kill Simcoe on her own; and Benedict Arnold defends himself in his own court-martial. Meanwhile, Ben reunites with the woman who saved his life.
The Culper Ring is resurrected in time to save Washington's army; and Simcoe terrorizes Setauket as he hunts for Rogers. Meanwhile, Anna infiltrates New York.
Benedict Arnold plots to turn over West Point to the British; and Andre negotiates for Peggy. Meanwhile, Abe plots revolt in Setauket.
In the third-season finale, there is an inevitable march to the gallows for the captured spies on both sides. Meanwhile, Benedict Arnold demands glory revenge.
A spy in London sends an urgent message to America; Mary impedes Abe's attempt to restart the spy ring; Benedict Arnold arrives in camp.
Abe gathers intelligence in New York; Simcoe escapes his punishment; John Andre attends a ball in Philadelphia and meets Peggy Shippen.
Ben sets a trap to capture a traitor in camp; Richard discovers Abe is conspiring with Major Hewlett; Caleb collides with Robert Rogers.
Abe tries to recruit a new agent in New York; Caleb races Rogers as they hunt down intelligence from London; Andre's history is exposed.
Abe makes a last-ditch effort to recruit a spy inside New York. Meanwhile, Ben must determine which of two deserters is a double agent.
Mary pleads with Richard to help free Abe from prison; Anna must seduce Simcoe; Ben and Caleb plot to rescue Hewlett from his captors.
Washington faces a personal crisis with the help of his slave Billy Lee. Meanwhile, Abe struggles to maintain his cover while in prison.
Caleb sails a one-man submersible into New York Harbor; France becomes an ally to America; Andre and Peggy plot to elope.
Abe returns from prison with critical intel; tensions rise between Hewlett and Simcoe; Arnold rescues Peggy from a rebel mob.
In the Season 2 finale, Abe plots to assassinate Major Hewlett; Ben fights at the Battle of Monmouth; and Benedict Arnold continues to covet Peggy Shippen.
The story of America's first spy ring is told in this drama, which opens with Long Island farmer Abraham Woodhull being recruited to spy on the British during the Revolutionary War.
"Who By Fire" Abe must discover who murdered a Royal Officer before Anna is framed for the crime. Ben and Caleb brutally interrogate Simcoe. AMC Original
Ben is betrayed by his own militia while on the run from the British. Meanwhile, Abe and Richard travel to New York to spy, and Mary confronts Anna.
Abe and Richard struggle with British orders to dig up local gravestones. Meanwhile, Ben and Caleb conspire to get their intelligence to Gen. Washington.
Caleb and Ben follow mysterious orders as Gen. Washington's Army crosses into enemy territory.
Abe is ambushed by a desperate patriot on the way to New York. Meanwhile, Gen. Washington charges Ben with the task of creating America's first spy ring.
Abe risks everything to protect Anna when an old threat returns to Setauket. Meanwhile, Rogers travels to a prison ship seeking a mysterious man.
Against Abe's wishes, Anna searches for enemy intelligence at an exclusive gentleman's party hosted by British spymaster John Andre.
"Against Thy Neighbor" Simcoe ignites a political witch-hunt to weed out rebel conspirators in Setauket. Washington assigns Ben to a secret mission. AMC Original
In the first-season finale, Mary grapples with the realization that Abe is a rebel spy. Meanwhile, Ben and Caleb lead a raid on Setauket to save the Patriot families.

"The challenge is to save civilization itself," says environmentalist Lester Brown in this documentary based on his "Plan B" book. He fears that unless carbon emissions are quickly curbed, the world faces cataclysmic changes that will lead to the collapse of many countries. The film, which follows him on a world speaking tour, features his solutions for averting disaster; and includes remarks from Thomas Friedman (New York Times) and economist Paul Krugman. Matt Damon hosts and narrates.
The health of the world's oceans, and how it's affecting coastal ecosystems, fisheries and marine preserves in the U.S. and around the world, is examined. Matt Damon hosts.

The fifth-season opener examines threats to marine species, half of which may face extinction in the next 25 years due to global warming, sea-level changes, overfishing and destruction of their habitats. Included: salmon and sea otters in the Pacific Northwest; loggerhead turtles in Florida; emperor penguins in the Antarctic; and coral reefs of the Caribbean and Indonesia.

The fourth-season opener examines why almost half of the world's wildlife species may die out within the next few decades. Included: the roles of climate change, poverty, poaching and the bush-meat trade in extinction. Also: ranchers who are creating marshes and bird sanctuaries on their lands.

"State of the Planet," Part 1 of a two-part environmental pulse-taking, explores challenges facing the planet. The biggest ones: global warming and lack of clean water. Matt Damon hosts the program, which looks at the effects of urbanization and industrialization on water and land.

A trip to the Canadian Arctic, Mexico, California and Uzbekistan to explore pollution's toll. In Canada, seals---and people---are being harmed by soot from factories thousands of miles south. But elsewhere the source of the pollution is much closer: a Soviet farming experiment gone awry, destroying the Aral Sea; industrial activity in Tijuana and a San Diego barrio. In these places, residents are victims of what host Matt Damon calls "environmental discrimination."

"On the Brink" (Part 1 of 3) examines the link between environmental pressures and political instability in visits to South Africa, Bangladesh, Peru and Haiti, and the U.S.-Mexican border. In Bangladesh, monsoon-season flooding often turns catastrophic; at other times of the year farmers face drought. In Peru, land scarcity led to a bloody insurrection. And in Haiti, deforestation provides "a case study of a country verging on a complete economic and environmental collapse." Matt Damon narrates.

Part 2. The environmental and economic impact of the degradation of grasslands around the world are explored. Some of the places visited include Argentinean pampas, Mongolian steppes, Kenyan savannas, South African plains and North American prairies. Matt Damon hosts.
The conclusion explores links between ecoystem changes and the spread of infectious diseases. Filmed in Kenya, Peru, Bangladesh, New York City and Maryland's Chesapeake Bay. Matt Damon hosts.
Examining dangers posed to various river systems. Included: the Mississippi, Amazon, Jordan and the Mekong Delta. Narrated by Kelly McGillis.
"Urban Explosion" examines the impact of the population boom on four cities: Mexico City, Istanbul, Shanghai and New York. Narrated by Kelly McGillis.
Examining agricultural and environmental issues related to the growing need to feed world populations. Included: farm areas in Zimbabwe, France, China and the U.S. Narrated by Kelly McGillis.

Ozzie tries to get the group back together in the Season 2 opener. Also: A disgraced FBI agent arrives to investigate white-collar crook Jonathan Walsh; a merger takes place on the ship; and Don and Kelly go to visit his "dying mother" in Iceland.

Agent Foster meets with StarCrossed in her continued investigation of Walsh. Meanwhile, Yvonne leads a small team to search for Gerry, unaware that he's been abducted. On the ship, Jeff seeks advice from Gerry on how to deal with his new boss.

Gerry returns to Earth, but his relationship with Yvonne is jeopardized. He returns to StarCrossed, excited to be a full-fledged member. Also: Father Doug and Chelsea go on their first real date; Ozzie and Agent Foster make contact with Jonathan Walsh.

Gina distracts Agent Foster so that Ozzie can sneak away to meet Walsh. Meanwhile, the Cube pressures Jeff to clean the ship, Don wants to spill a secret to Kelly, and it proves difficult for Father Doug and Chelsea to break off previous commitments.
Ozzie confronts Walsh about being an alien; and Richard gets fired from his job and joins Agent Foster on her search for Walsh.
The group copes with a tragedy. Agent Foster reports back to the FBI. Jonathan Walsh and Don have reservations about the alien mission.
The group asks Agent Foster for help with an investigation; Chelsea and her husband go to marriage counseling; and Jeff blames Don for bringing an intruder onto the ship.

The group attends an alien experiencer convention; Gina meets one of her therapy heroes; Gerry and Yvonne have their first fight; Richard tries to prove to Agent Foster that aliens do exist; and both Chelsea and Agent Foster receive unexpected news.

Agent Foster goes to Gina with a personal problem. Richard sues his employer for wrongful termination with the help of the group as character witnesses. Jeff is blackmailed by Eric and Jonathan Walsh offers his support.
Gerry and Yvonne host a group game night. Agent Foster meets a person from her past. Walsh, Jeff, Don, and Kurt enact their mutiny against Eric.
New York journalist Ozzie Graham (Wyatt Cenac) arrives at a support group for alien abductees when investigating a suspicious car accident in the series premiere of this ensemble comedy.
Gerry tries to win Ozzie over. Meanwhile, Chelsea opens up to Father Doug about her marriage, and tensions escalate when Jeff, Don and Kurt prepare for an alien invasion.
Richard faces his shattered marriage with help from Ozzie. Meanwhile, Yvonne and Gerry snoop into a mysterious cover-up, and Jonathan Walsh gives unsettling news to Jeff and Don.
Ozzie's former boss makes an unexpected visit to Beacon. Meanwhile, Gina goes down memory lane as the origin of StarCrossed is revealed.
Unexplained visions and hallucinations plague Ozzie. Meanwhile, Chelsea and Father Doug bond over Bible study, and Kelly grapples with relationships.
Ozzie and Father Doug go out for the night. Meanwhile, Gina hosts a coming-out event for StarCrossed members, and Jeff bonds with an online stranger.
Gerry bids adieu to StarCrossed while counting down to his own anticipated "experience." In addition, Jonathan Walsh shares important information with Ozzie, and Don and Kelly go on a date.
Ozzie makes an unexpected confession during an interview. Meanwhile, Father Doug has an experience, and Jeff sets out to find Kurt's killer.
Ozzie seeks a life of normalcy and leaves Beacon. Meanwhile, Chelsea hits the road with Operation Mongoose, and the StarCrossed members mull over an uncertain future.

Ozzie has an important breakthrough in the Season 1 finale. Also: Jeff and Jonathan Walsh clash following an impending invasion, and the StarCrossed members seek meaning in the wake of the group's parting.

In the Season 4 premiere, Pamela finds her place within the group as they all set sail for Mexico, avoiding the apocalyptic nuclear fallout in the U.S. Their course derails a bit when they realize that none of them knows how to actually navigate a yacht.
Tandy devises an escape plan to get away from Pamela and back to Carol and the others. Meanwhile, the rest of the gang encounters a castaway, Glenn, who has been stranded on an island for years.
Pamela tries desperately to redeem herself with everyone, as the gang finally reaches Mexico. Meanwhile, Todd is disappointed that Zihuatanejo is not the paradise of which he'd dreamed.

Carol panics when Todd and Melissa leave for their honeymoon and Erica and Gail decide to live on their own for a while. She and Tandy devise the ultimate plan to convince everyone it's safer to stick together.

The gang settles into an old mansion previously owned by an infamous cartel leader. While Carol forces Tandy to put down his new toys so they can baby-proof the giant estate, Melissa worries about Todd's physical health; and Gail and Erica can't figure out why Dawn won't stop crying.
Carol's pregnancy takes an unexpected turn, and while Tandy feels ready to face the challenge head on, Gail is concerned and wants to intervene. Meanwhile, Melissa discourages Todd's baby fever.
Tandy goes to great lengths to convince everyone he's a feminist. Meanwhile, Carol gets jealous of the time that Gail spends with Erica and Dawn; and Todd tries to be a father figure to Jasper.
Todd asks Tandy for parenting advice when he notices Jasper acting more reckless than usual. Meanwhile, Carol and Erica realize that Jasper may be the only potential suitor for their babies.
Tandy and Todd stumble upon a new survivor, Karl, who has been trapped in a high-security prison in Mexico ever since the virus hit.
In the winter finale, Tandy and Todd introduce newcomer Karl to the rest of the gang. Meanwhile, the group searches for Jasper, who has gone missing.

Season 3 begins with Malibu under attack by a trio of armed invaders in hazmat suits, but when the group can't agree on how to thwart it, Melissa takes matters into her own hands, and Tandy gets a fashion lesson.
Todd is filled with remorse in the wake of all the recent chaos, so Phil tries to boost his morale, even it means stretching the truth.
Phil installs an alarm system in the house, but Melissa has already beaten him to it with her own security plans. Meanwhile, a change in scenery could do the group some good.
A post-apocalyptic road trip has everyone at war with each other. -- (C) FOX
The search for a new home isn't easy for the group, especially when someone may be deliberately trying to stop them. Meanwhile, the love triangle between Todd, Gail and Melissa starts losing steam.
Phil tries to make friends with Lewis by becoming interested in his life story. Meanwhile, Carol needs a favor from Gail; and Todd is concerned about Melissa's mental health.
A family photo shoot becomes Carol's obsession. Meanwhile, Lewis finds a new hobby; Melissa goes on a mission; and Gail stumbles into a frightening predicament.
Melissa leaves a note bidding the group farewell, so they set out to find out where she's gone. Meanwhile, Gail struggles to deal with her own adventure.
Phil hopes to cheer Carol up by treating her to a honeymoon vacation; Lewis' aviation pursuits prove to be a success.
A special lens reveals how the deadly virus got started.
Phil and Carol leave Tucson to take a road trip across the U.S. in the Season 2 premiere.
Phil looks for Carol after they're separated without phones or walkie-talkies. Later, a mysterious message from California has him thinking about a new place to live.
Carol tells a lie that puts her in an awkward position with the former Tucson crew in California.
Phil finds redemption in an uncharacteristically heroic way.
A big secret is revealed that is out of proportion with the world's small population.
An apocalyptic power problem tests Tandy and Todd's mettle.
The topic of re-population dominates the conversation among the survivors in Malibu.
Phil No. 2 causes problems in the group and joins Tandy in the doghouse.
The approach of Christmas gives Carol an idea to plan an anonymous gift exchange to get the others excited about the holiday season.
Gail is under pressure to make the best of a bad situation; Melissa Todd have trouble in paradise.
A deadly virus leaves Phil Miller thinking he is the last man on earth. He travels across the country looking for survivors and then heads back home to Tucson, Arizona.
Things don't go as well as expected when Phil finds another person on Earth.
Phil settles into his new mansion in Tucson, but his days of living alone are not without their surprises.
Phil and Carol find another survivor named Melissa after Phil agrees to marry Carol.
The topic of repopulation is a popular one in Tucson as Phil, Carol and Melissa look to the future.
A man named Todd shows up and could spoil Phil's chances with Melissa.
Phil becomes unhinged when he learns that Todd and Melissa are having sex-and lots of it.
Phil finds a cow, but can't agree with the rest of the group on what to do with it. Meanwhile, Carol seizes an opportunity to move in with Phil.
Phil's life in Tucson continues.
Phil can't persuade the group that running off with Erica and Gail was just a prank, so he tries a different strategy to get his point across.
Season 3 premiere. An examination of the global politics of a dangerous new Cold War as tensions between the U.S. and Russia are ratcheting up.

A look at the legal entanglements surrounding President Trump, including the Mueller investigation and the Michael Cohen raid. Also: interviews with attorneys Michael Avenatti and Alan Dershowitz; and former acting U.S. attorney general Sally Yates.

Mike Pompeo's nomination for Secretary of State; and state visits by French president Emmanuel Macron and German chancellor Angela Merkel are discussed. Also: former state department official Wendy Sherman on the Iran nuclear deal; Muslim Association of Hawaii imam Ismail Elshikh on President Trump's travel ban.

Celebrated Republican political strategist Steve Schmidt joins John Heilemann, Mark McKinnon and Alex Wagner as a guest host this week. From the industrial heartland to the Mountain West, and from the far North to the deep South, the team assesses Trump's impact on the national political climate, campaigns and candidates from both parties.
President Trump's first 100 days in office are the focus, as Season 2 begins.

The groundbreaking real-time political documentary series about America's presidential campaign returns, examining the unprecedented events unfolding in Donald Trump's administration. Journalists Mark Halperin and John Heilemann take the pulse of the country beyond the beltway while pulling back the curtain on a White House unlike any that has come before. -- (C) SHOWTIME

What do people outside the Beltway really think about President Trump? Mark Halperin takes a trip through America to find the answers. Then he heads to New Orleans to discuss his surprising findings with Mary Matalin.  -- (C) SHOWTIME

What in the world is going on? Mark Halperin heads to Palm Beach for Chinese President Xi Jinping's visit to Mar-A-Lago. A revealing look at how President Trump is handling American foreign policy and our relations with China.  -- (C) SHOWTIME

Congress may be in recess but Mark Halperin is on the job, covering the White House and the Syria fallout. John Heilemann and Mark McKinnon hit the road to see what Americans think about how President Trump is handling the situation. -- (C) SHOWTIME

Mark Halperin talks with Sen. Elizabeth Warren (D-Mass.) about standing strong against Trump; Sen. Bernie Sanders (I-Vt.) tells John Heilemann about taking his message to the people; Americans discuss what resistance means to them.

As Congress reconvenes, Mark McKinnon and John Heilemann head to Capitol Hill to find out what President Trump has learned in his first 100 days in office. Also, Mark Halperin goes to New York City to get Wall Street's perspective.

Washington insiders join John Heilemann, Mark Halperin and Mark McKinnon for a look at some of the thrilling, amazing and logic defying acts performed during President Trump's first 100 days. Season finale. -- (C) SHOWTIME
A real-time documentary series that offers a revealing look at the 2016 presidential race. In the opener, Ted Cruz, Bernie Sanders and Donald Trump campaign in Iowa.
A real-time documentary series that offers a revealing look at the 2016 presidential race.

A look at the angst and drama leading up to the Iowa Caucuses, with a showdown brewing between Democrats Bernie Sanders and Hillary Clinton, and the GOP's first real test of outsider candidates versus the establishment.
A look at the Iowa fallout and an examination of who has momentum going into the New Hampshire primary, and whether Trump and Clinton can pick up the pace to beat back the surging Cruz and Sanders.
The candidates deal with the jolt that was New Hampshire and prepare for hard truths in South Carolina and Nevada.
Anxiety grows among the candidates about the high stakes in South Carolina and Nevada, and the significance of falling behind.

With the field narrowed down to The Big Five, the campaigns spread their game across the country and play to their strengths--with eyes squarely focused on the all-important upcoming prize: Super Tuesday.
Candidates who trail the front-runners deal with the results of Super Tuesday, while the Democratic and Republican establishments try to find a way to stop Trump.
Rubio, Kasich and Sanders pin their hopes on Florida and Ohio in hopes of gaining enough momentum to force a brokered convention.
As Rubio gets trumped in Florida, the rest of the field remains optimistic.  -- (C) Showtime
